title: Chugwater Tour de Chili
description: New for the 26th Annual Chugwater Chili Cook-off, we would like for you to join us for the 1st Annual Tour de Chili Fun Ride. Use this as a race season warm-up, or simply to jump-start your appetite for some fantastic chili and a day filled with entertainment!  We will kick off the ride at 8 AM, Saturday, June 18, 2011.  Proceeds will benefit Chugwater non-profit organizations.
course: There are two scenic out-and-back options, 45k or 24k. Both will begin in Chugwater, and head east of town and then back to the staging area.
registration: Registration is being offered online through USA Cycling, or by mail. The cost is $25 per rider plus $5 per rider if you need a one day USAC license (plus service charge for online registration) and includes many gifts. All riders need a USAC license since this is a sanctioned event.(one day or annual) If you have a current annual license, you will need to show it during check-in. For more information or for mail-in forms check us out at https://sites.google.com/site/chugwatertourdechili/ or email tourdechili@gmail.com
notes: The 45k option is a combination of two-and-back routes, and the 24k option is the first leg of the long route.  Both are on good rural roads and offer some beautiful Wyoming scenery. All riders are required to wear a helmet and to follow the rules of the road, as we are not closing down the roads to traffic, though traffic is usually very slow on the roads we\'ll be riding! Also, this ride is permitted under USA Cycling, and we will follow all USA Cycling guidelines.
directions: Chugwater, WY is located at exit 54 on I-25.  Take the exit and follow the signs to the check-in area.

title: 23rd annual Cook-Sanders and The Spence Law Firm H
Laramie Enduro 2011
description: Situated in the Laramie Range of Southeastern Wyoming, the course is a challenging 72.5 miles climbing over 8,600 vertical feet, all above 7,500 feet elevation. The route is a fast and extremely fun loop, covering no ground twice, except the initial/final 0.8 miles. It includes virtually every kind of trail and surface a mountain biker is likely to encounter in the Rockies, from wildlife trails to single track to dirt roads. This event is not for the casual or beginner rider.
course: 72.5 miles, the initial/final 0.8 miles is repeated in opposite directions. We are not allowed to post the map on the website per USFS requirement.
registration: Maximum racer limit 500 participants; $75 per rider before May 1, 2011; $95 per rider after April 30, 2011; On-line registration link posted on website; Packet pick-up on Friday July 29, 3-8 PM (TBD refer to website for contact information); Absolutely, NO RACE DAY REGISTRATION OR Packet Pick-up
notes: Race proceeds benefit the Albany County Chapter of the American Red Cross of Wyoming, Medicine Bow Mountain Bike Patrol, and other local and regional non-profit organizations. Laramie Enduro is a 501(C)3 Non-Profit Organization. http://www.LarmieEnduro.org.
directions: From Laramie: Travel approximately 9.5 miles east (of the Grand Ave. Exit) on I-80. Take the Summit Rest Area Exit (Exit 323), turn left (towards the rest area) and continue straight on USFS Road 705 (Blair-Wallis Road) past the Summit Rest Area. Follow the Blair-Wallis Road for approximately 0.5 miles and look for the parking signs (race parking will be on the left along Road 705F-No Parking along Road 705. Proceed another 0.3 miles down Road 705 to the Hidden Valley Picnic Area - follow signs to the parking & start areas. From Cheyenne: Travel approximately 39 miles west on I-80 take the Summit Rest Area Exit (Exit 323) turn right (towards the rest area) and continue straight on USFS Road 705 â€“ from that point follow directions listed above.

title: McCullough Peaks Wild Horse Century
description:
The McCullough Peaks Wild Horse Century is a very unique event to benefit the wild mustangs of the McCullough Peaks  outside Cody Wyoming.  The joint sponsorship of Friends of a Legacy ( FOAL) and Park County Pedalers (PCP) will offer a century bicycle ride on September 10th, 2011.  Proceeds from this ride will go towards the care of the wild horses.  Options for a shorter ride will also be provided.
 
With a little luck you will be able to see the wild horses right from your bicycle seat.  Rest stops will be set up to enable viewing of the horses while you gather nourishment for the next leg of the ride.  The ride will travel around the BLM lands that are home to these magnificent mustangs.   Besides the century ride there will also be other options and things to do.  Special accommodations are also being provided by the Cody Legacy Inn, right across the street from the starting point.
course:
The ride will follow established roads from which wild horses are seen year round.  Rest stops will be offered along the way as will full SAG support.  The FOAL organization will host the rest stops and offer viewing stations and experts to spot the wild horses.  FOAL has land which is accessible from the highway and is also adjacent to the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) lands where the wild horses live.

In summary the ride will have three options depending on how much you wish to ride.  Each option will leave from the Absaroka Bicycle Shop in  Cody, Wyoming and follow Route 14-16-20 heading east along the BLM lands.  One option will be to turn around once reaching Burlington, Wyoming and returning the way you came for about 60 miles.  The other options continue North on highway 32 just past Burlington, Wyoming.  The next option is to turn left onto highway 295 and cut over to Highway 14 and continue back to Cody.  This would give you about 82 miles   The full ride would continue to Byron, Wyoming and then return to Cody thru Powell Wyoming on Highway 14.  This gives you a full century. 

Post ride picnic will be held at Beck Lake behind Absaroka Bicycles.
registration: Go to www.wildhorsecentury.com and click on the \'Sign Up\' tab
directions: Starts from Absaroka Bicycles in Cody Wy
